title: 106_hr2352
content: The Act may be cited as the "International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1999". The Congress finds that arbitration is a valuable dispute resolution mechanism for US persons doing business internationally, especially in countries with unreliable judicial systems. The effectiveness of international arbitration relies on foreign states' commitment to enforce arbitral awards under the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. US persons often lack remedies when foreign states fail to uphold the Convention. Foreign states violate the Convention by refusing to enforce foreign arbitral awards or impairing the ability to collect them. It is in the interest of the United States to maintain the reliability of international arbitration and protect US persons from economic injury. Creating a judicial remedy for US persons injured by foreign states is in the national interest. Judicial remedy for US persons injured by foreign states under the Convention to facilitate judgment execution. The purpose of this Act is to create a civil remedy against foreign states violating the Convention, prohibiting enforcement of foreign arbitral awards in favor of US persons or impairing their ability to collect such awards. The Act defines key terms such as "Convention," "United States person," and "foreign arbitral award." It also establishes liability for violations of the Convention. The Act establishes a civil remedy for foreign states certified by the President for injuring a US person through a violation of the Convention regarding a foreign arbitral award. The remedy includes the amount of the award, interest, and attorney's fees. Actions can be taken for awards before or after the Act's enactment. Presidential certification is required for the injury. The Act provides a civil remedy for foreign states that fail to enforce or impede the enforcement of a foreign arbitral award in favor of a US person, in violation of the Convention. The US person must have exhausted all remedies in the foreign state, or further pursuit would be futile. Presidential certification is required for the remedy to take effect. The Act establishes a presumption that a foreign state violated the Convention if a US person is injured, with damages equivalent to the award amount. District courts have exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions related to violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1999 amends chapter 85 of title 28, United States Code, regarding actions brought under section 5. The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1999 amends section 1605 of title 28, US Code, regarding civil actions involving violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. It also addresses waiver of sovereign immunity and no immunity from attachment or execution under section 1610(a). The International Arbitration Enforcement Act of 1999 amends section 1605 and 1610 of title 28, US Code, regarding civil actions involving violations of the Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards. It addresses waiver of sovereign immunity and no immunity from attachment or execution for claims not immune under section 1605(a)(8). An action under the International Arbitration Enforcement Act must be brought within one year after the President certifies the basis for the claim.
